hedline.hl2: Elected Chief of Turkey Warns Army

body.head.byline: By SABRINA TAVERNISE; Sebnem Arsu contributed reporting.

abstract.p: Turkish government spokesman says military was out of line when it issued warning that it would move against government of Prime Min Recep Tayyip Erdogan if religion is allowed to enter too far into politics; says government is elected, and military is under its control; confrontation has crystallized around vote for Erdogan's choice for president, Abdullah Gul (M)

block.p: Turkey's government struck back at the country's powerful military on Saturday, declaring that the army is not above the law or the government that commands it.

A government spokesman, Cemil Cicek, said at a news conference that the military was out of line when it issued a warning late Friday that it would move against the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan if religion was allowed to enter too far into politics. The government, he said, is elected, and the military is under its control.

Turkey's government struck back at the country's powerful military on Saturday, declaring that the army is not above the law or the government that commands it.

A government spokesman, Cemil Cicek, said at a news conference that the military was out of line when it issued a warning late Friday that it would move against the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan if religion was allowed to enter too far into politics. The government, he said, is elected, and the military is under its control.

''It is inconceivable in a democratic state that the general staff would use any phrase against the government on any matter,'' said Mr. Cicek, who is also the justice minister. His remarks were broadcast on Turkey's NTV. ''The chief of the general staff, in terms of his duty and authority, is accountable to the prime minister.''

Mr. Cicek's remarks raised the stakes in a contest of wills between the country's secular establishment -- its military, constitutional court and president -- and Mr. Erdogan, an agile advocate of change whose background in political Islam has set the establishment against him.

The military, one of the most powerful forces in the Turkish state, has initiated four coups against elected governments since 1960, most recently in 1997. It considers itself the protector of the secular legacy of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, Turkey's founder.

The confrontation has crystallized around a vote for Mr. Erdogan's choice for president, Abdullah Gul, a close political ally. The president is commander in chief, a post at the very heart of Turkey's secular establishment.

The first of several rounds of votes in Parliament was held Friday. All of Turkey's secular political parties boycotted that round, and one appealed to the country's constitutional court to have the vote annulled. Mr. Erdogan said he would call early elections if the court agreed. It is expected to rule by Wednesday.
Mr. Cicek said he suspected that the army's statement was timed to influence the court while it was deliberating.
Also on Saturday, Mr. Erdogan spoke by telephone to Gen. Yasar Buyukanit, the chief of staff, Mr. Cicek said.

In Brussels, Olli Rehn, the European Union commissioner responsible for enlarging the organization's membership, was quoted by Reuters as saying, ''This is a test case if the Turkish armed forces respect democratic secularism and the democratic arrangement of civil-military relations.''
Mr. Erdogan's government has been pushing for Turkey to gain European Union membership.
